text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to claim that environmental obligations cannot form the basis of any counterclaim under international law. The candidate answer does not make this claim. In fact, the candidate answer explicitly discusses cases where tribunals *accepted* counterclaims based on environmental obligations, provided they were sufficiently connected to the investment treaty claim (e.g., *CMS Energy v. Argentina* and *Tethyan Copper v. Eritrea*). The response suggests that environmental claims *can* form the basis of a counterclaim if framed correctly (i.e., as a breach of a treaty obligation incorporating domestic law, or arising from the same transaction). Therefore, the criterion is not satisfied.", "criterion_id": "4039082c-276f-47cd-ad4b-06fd8b91be97"}
